prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As described in the scientific justification, we do not require ACA observations because we are directly modeling the observed visibilities with a dust continuum radiative transfer code. The largest angular extent is "faked" to get AOT validation (see below) - we know that the source is extended beyond 60 arc sec, but direct modeling of visibilities obviates the need for the ACA. We have already generated best-fit radiative transfer models using Bonnor-Ebert spheres that simultaneously match the observed intensity profiles at 850, 500, 350, and 250 um as well as the SED from 160 - 850 um for each source. The PI has developed a Python script that can "observe" a model intensity distribution with the actual u,v tracks from an ALMA observations (interfaces with CASA). The best fit model will be found by running through the grid of physical models and different dust beta and minimizing the chi^2 of the observed visibility amplitudes. The results will then be compared to the results from single-dish modeling.
The 1.2 mm observations overlap the existing MAMBO single-dish observations in wavelength. We request a configuration (C34-1 is best) that provides between 1-2" arc sec resolution (120 - 240 AU spatial resolution) while imaging the inner 11" of the core. Since the MRS corresponds to the MAMBO resolution, we only require a single pointing. Time estimates are derived from the observed single-dish peak flux density of each core scaled by the ratio of ALMA synthetic beam solid angle to single-dish beam solid angle and assuming beta = 2 with an assumed dust temperature equivalent to the central temperature found in the best-fit radiative transfer model. For the weakest core (L1696A), we can achieve a 4-sigma detection with 6.72 min of on source integration (target sensitivity per pointing of 55 uJy). For consistency, we request the same target continuum sensitivity level for all 5 cores. The total time request is 1.02 hours to observe 4 cores within 10 degrees of each other which can easily be observed in one session. These observations are important for bridging the gap between the ends of the "lever-arm" to calculate beta (the dust opacity index) and provide a means of mitigating absolute flux calibration errors in the determination of beta.

As described in the scientific justification, we do not require ACA observations because we are directly modeling the observed visibilities with a dust continuum radiative transfer code. The largest angular extent is "faked" to get AOT validation (see below) - we know that the source is extended over 60 arc sec, but direct modeling of the visibilties obviates the need for the ACA. We have already generated best-fit radiative transfer models using Bonnor-Ebert spheres that simultaneously match the observed intensity profiles at 850, 500, 350, and 250 um as well as the SED from 160 - 850 um for each source. The PI has developed a Python script that can "observe" a model intensity distribution with the actual u,v tracks from an ALMA observations (interfaces with CASA). The best fit model will be found by running through the grid of physical models and different dust beta and minimizing the chi^2 of the observed visibility amplitudes. The results will then be compared to the results from single-dish modeling.
The 0.86 mm observations overlap the existing SCUBA single-dish observations in wavelength. We request a configuration (C34-1 is best) that provides between 1-2" resolution (120-240 AU spatial resolution) while imaging the inner 15" of the core. Since the IRS is only 7.6", we request a 3-point mosaic. The spacing and position of the mosaic offsets are those recommended but the ALMA OT for a rectangular 15"x15" field. Time estimates are derived from the observed single-dish peak flux density of each core scaled by the ratio of ALMA synthetic beam solid angle to single-dish beam solid angle and assuming beta = 2 with an assumed dust temperature equivalent to the central temperature found in the best-fit radiative transfer model. For the weakest core (L1696A), we can achieve a 4-sigma detection with 1.2 min of on source integration/pointing (target sensitivity of 200 uJy). For consistency, we request the same target continuum sensitivity level for all 5 cores. The total time request is 49 minutes to observe 4 cores within 10 deg of each other which can easily be observed in one session.

As described in the scientific justification, we do not require ACA observations because we are directly modeling the observed visibilities with a dust continuum radiative transfer code. The largest angular extent is "faked" to get AOT validation (see below) - we know that the source is extended over 60 arc sec, but direct modeling of the visibilties obviates the need for the ACA. We have already generated best-fit radiative transfer models using Bonnor-Ebert spheres that simultaneously match the observed intensity profiles at 850, 500, 350, and 250 um as well as the SED from 160 - 850 um for each source. The PI has developed a Python script that can "observe" a model intensity distribution with the actual u,v tracks from an ALMA observations (interfaces with CASA). The best fit model will be found by running through the grid of physical models and different dust beta and minimizing the chi^2 of the observed visibility amplitudes. The results will then be compared to the results from single-dish modeling.
Unlike 0.86mm and 1.2 mm, the 2.1 mm observations have no ground-based counterpart. We request. We request a configuration (C34-1 is best) that provides between 1-2" arc sec resolution (120 - 240 AU spatial resolution) while imaging the inner 12" of the core. Since the MRS overlaps with the 0.86mm and 1.2mm MRS, we only request 1 pointing. Time estimates are derived from the observed single-dish peak flux density of each core scaled by the ratio of ALMA synthetic beam solid angle to single-dish beam solid angle and assuming beta = 2 with an assumed dust temperature equivalent to the central temperature found in the best-fit radiative transfer model. For the weakest core (L1696A), we can achieve a 4-sigma detection with 19.76 min of on source integration (target sensitivity per pointing of 25 uJy). For consistency, we request the same target continuum sensitivity level for all 5 cores. The total time request is 2.71 hours to observe 4 cores within 10 deg of each other which can easily be observed in one session.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B68 1.2 mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 1.2mm Continuum setup. B68 is more than 10 deg away from other Oph sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As described in the scientific justification, we do not require ACA observations because we are directly modeling the observed visibilities with a dust continuum radiative transfer code. The largest angular extent is "faked" to get AOT validation (see below) - we know that the source is extended over 60 arc sec, but direct modeling of the visibilities obviates the need for the ACA. We have already generated best-fit radiative transfer models using Bonnor-Ebert spheres that simultaneously match the observed intensity profiles at 850, 500, 350, and 250 um as well as the SED from 160 - 850 um for each source. The PI has developed a Python script that can "observe" a model intensity distribution with the actual u,v tracks from an ALMA observations (interfaces with CASA). The best fit model will be found by running through the grid of physical models and different dust beta and minimizing the chi^2 of the observed visibility amplitudes. The results will then be compared to the results from single-dish modeling.
The 1.2 mm observations overlap the existing MAMBO single-dish observations in wavelength. We request a configuration (C34-1 is best) that provides between 1-2" arc sec resolution (120 - 240 AU spatial resolution) while imaging the inner 11" of the core. For the weakest core (L1696A), we can achieve a 4-sigma detection with 6.72 min of on source integration (target sensitivity per pointing of 55 uJy). For consistency, we request the same target continuum sensitivity level for all 5 cores. The total time request is 32.15 hours to observe B68. These observations are important for bridging the gap between the ends of the "lever-arm" to calculate beta (the dust opacity index) and provide a means of mitigating absolute flux calibration errors in the determination of beta.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B68 0.86 mm Setup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: B68 0.86mm Continuum setup. B68 is more than 10 deg away from other Oph sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As described in the scientific justification, we do not require ACA observations because we are directly modeling the observed visibilities with a dust continuum radiative transfer code. The largest angular extent is "faked" to get AOT validation (see below) - we know that the source is extended over 60 arc sec, but direct modeling of the visibilties obviates the need for the ACA. We have already generated best-fit radiative transfer models using Bonnor-Ebert spheres that simultaneously match the observed intensity profiles at 850, 500, 350, and 250 um as well as the SED from 160 - 850 um for each source. The PI has developed a Python script that can "observe" a model intensity distribution with the actual u,v tracks from an ALMA observations (interfaces with CASA). The best fit model will be found by running through the grid of physical models and different dust beta and minimizing the chi^2 of the observed visibility amplitudes. The results will then be compared to the results from single-dish modeling.
The 0.86 mm observations overlap the existing SCUBA single-dish observations in wavelength. We request a configuration (C34-1 is best) that provides between 1-2" resolution (120-240 AU spatial resolution) while imaging the inner 15" of the core. Since the IRS is only 7.6", we request a 3-point mosaic. The spacing and position of the mosaic offsets are those recommended but the ALMA OT for a rectangular 15"x15" field. For the weakest core (L1696A), we can achieve a 4-sigma detection with 1.2 min of on source integration/pointing (target sensitivity of 200 uJy). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With the windfall of recent continuum observations of nearby star-forming regions using Herschel and large ground-based bolometer arrays, it is imperative that we reduce the factor of a few uncertainty that currently exists in (sub)millimeter dust opacities. This uncertainty strongly affects determination of the core mass distribution and core stability. In this proposal, we will directly address two key issues in studies of the nascent phase of star formation - starless cores: (1) what is the dust opacity index (beta) at (sub)millimeter wavelengths, and (2) do starless cores fragment on scales of 100 - 1500 AU? We shall observe a sample of 5 bright, nearby (125 pc) starless cores in the Ophiuchus cloud complex at 2.1, 1.2, and 0.86 mm at 100 AU resolution. We will determine the dust opacity index by radiative transfer modeling of the observed visibilities and compare the results to existing 160-1200 um observations. Our sample includes cores with a range of central densities (1.0e5 - 1.0e6 cm-3) and dynamical states (stable to collapsing) in which to search for fragmentation and to search for variations among the cores in the dust opacity index.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of
